country:
None
text:
Pretty tasty stuff.  I didn't blend this and really can't see why you'd have to.  Just throw it into a ziploc bag and mix is up.  I cut the marinade in half because I had just two steaks.  I used a bunch of minced garlic instead of garlic powder and also skipped on the hot sauce.  I ended up letting it sit in the fridge with the steaks (top sirloin) for about 3 hours.  When it was time to make dinner, I took the steaks out of the bag and then threw in 8 ounces of sliced mushrooms until they were well coated and dropped all of that into a pan.  I cooked the mushrooms until most of the liquid was cooked out on medium high heat.  Grilled the steaks to medium rare, then served the mushrooms on top!  Turned out very flavorful and very delicious.  Thanks!

text:
This marinade was amazing.  I really wasn't sure about the ingredients (didn't want teriyaki type), and decided to take a chance based upon the ratings.  Boy, was I glad I did.  The steaks ended up marinating 3 days (due to changes in plans).  They were so tender, and the taste... fabulous.  This marinade is very subtle, it really enhances the meat well.  I didn't have parsley, so I added a dash of thyme.  My DH was extremely happy with the taste, and wants me to use this recipe again and again.
***UPDATE***-I wanted something different for Christmas dinner for 15 people, this was my choice, and everyone raved about how flavorful and tender the steaks were (we used flat iron steaks).  I brought the steaks home from the store, fixed the marinade, popped them in the freezer for about a week, then defrosted them Christmas Eve.  My DH put them on the BBQ to cook, YUMMM!  On a busy day, it was an effortless, but outstanding main dish.

text:
Steak purist as he is, hubs preferred his steak without this marinade and didn't use it.  In hindsight I wish I would have followed suit. Thank goodness l at least used fresh garlic, but I think both the lemon juice and hefty amount of garlic powder contributed a strong, "off flavor," as one reviewer put it, that I just didn't care for - not so sure I liked the basil either.  It was fun to experiment, but it would have been so much easier and so much better to have just stuck with the simple steak seasonings we're accustomed to.  When something is really good, like a good quality steak, it simply doesn't need anything to make it better.

text:
I don't know if this is "THE BEST" steak marinade, but it comes in close.  I used this on two pretty large NY stips and it came out great!  I cut the olive oil down to 1/4 c. and used all minced garlic, no powders. I used 2 Tbsp. of dried basil and 1 Tbsp. of oregano.  I didn't have white pepper, so I used 1/2 tsp. of black pepper.  I put everything into a ziplock bag and let it marinate all day.  Perfect with a baked potato and salad!

text:
This is good, but I have been doing the "exact ingredients for over 20 years. You "do not" need to blend ingredients in a blender at all. In fact, if, after tasting "mixture", it seems "to strong for your taste buds", just an a little water to it.". I also always add "a little oil or canola oil" to the mixture(it depends how much you make, but "at least a tablespoon". It tenderizes the steak/pork/or venison" meat, and gives the flames on the grill a chance to "dance upward", giving those nice "charred lines>

I also use both powered garlic and real garlic. I subsitute lemon juice with "rice flavored vinegar or wine vinegar. Be sure "not to over due the acidic ingredients(lemon or vinegars)If you have "fresh basil leave handy, instead of dry..even better. I always "freeze "fresh basil leaves" in a ziploc baggie, to have handy in the house. Just crush the leaves once from, grab a handful to add to your "marinades or pasta sauces. Makes a "huge difference in flavor.
Sometimes, instead of "soy", I'll use Terriyaki sauce instead, or sometimes "a little of each". Especially with "pork tenderloins. Even throw in chopped green onions. Once you are "comfortable making your own marinades, "the "skys the limit". You also , if a tender cut of meat(like pork or beef or venison tenderloin", do not have to marinate "more than a half hour".  Marinades will stay in a glass jar up to a week, if you do not have time to do it "daily". I send up a batch with my husband went he goes hunting

country:
None
text:
The problem with marinades that are intensely acidic is that they make the surface of the meat mushy, gray, and resistant to browning.   I have made a version of this marinade with only a tablespoon of lemon juice and the zest of one lemon for flavor, and the texture was markedly better.  I also used fresh herbs, as dried herbs have an off flavor.  I would not suggest anybody use a third of a cup of lemon juice, as the acid does not actually tenderize the meat past the first few millimeters of the surface, which becomes waterlogged and broken down by the acid.

text:
This marinade was simply wonderful. We have been cutting back on expesnses in our home, which includes not eating out. I have been doing by best to deliver resturant quality dishes so that no one gets board. This did not fail! My fiance just raved over it. The only thing I changed was that a few mintues before the meat was done cooking, I sprinkled a little bit of turbanado sugar on the meat to balance the salt. It was to die for! By the way, although you dont have have to blend the ingredents together with a processor, I hightly recommend it. This really allows the flavors to mix, the herbs to be ground (which increased the flavor of any herb) and the oil to be infused with the flavors of this marinade. Dont hesitated to try this one!

It was very easy to put together...I skipped the blender part and just mixed it in a bowl, put the steaks in ziploc bags and poured the marinade in. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm afraid I was just a bit disappointed by this marinade. Still, at 4 stars, it was pretty good. I definitely agree that the ingredients should be mixed in a blender so they are uniform. This also makes the marinade very thick so it sticks to the meat extremely well - but this is part of the problem. Because of its thickness, even after grilling there is so still much marinade coating the meat that it is overpowering - the flavor of the meat gets lost in the marinade. So, the solution is simple - make sure you wipe most of the marinade off before you cook the meat! With this one addition to the directions, it might have gotten 5 stars from me.

text:
I just put the ingredients in a ziploc bag, add the meat and squeeze out the air. Blending isn't necessary. I often do several steaks at a time and pop the bags in the freezer so the meat is ready for the grill on short notice. This is very flavorful and especially good on kabobs and London Broil. I've used this recipe for a few years and it's become the "house marinade" because it's never failed to tenderize a piece of beef or generate a compliment. It can be tweaked for variety's sake and doesn't require exact measurements. A tip of the hat to you Kookie!

With all the soy sace, lemon juice and worchestershire it made the meat very sour and almost made it taste rancid.  I was a little disappointed in how many ingredients I wasted to make it.  I think maybe if the measurements were right, with a little tweaking, this could be a good recipe.  Maybe using fresh herbs instead of dried would be better as well.  Overall, it needs some work.

userID:
4452539
Display Name:
zzmegz
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
26
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
THIS HAS TO BE THE BEST MARINADE IN THE WORLD! 

Marinaded for 6 hours- Turn the Grill on HIGH and with the lid down get the inside temp to 400, (wait untill its up there), sear the meat on all sides opening and the lid to to check and flip. When seared or blackened to desired crust, turn the grill on LOW to cool it, untill the temperature gets down to about 275 or 300. When the grill cools down you can  close the lid and cook the meat turning occasionally until the  inside temperature of the meat is to the desired temperature.  (150 is good) Take the meat out on plate cover with a dish cloth for about 10 min to let the meat rest. Nothing else needed. 

This is the marinade I chose to use for the tenderloins at the company picnic.There were 3 tenderlions about 3 lbs each, 9 lbs total. I doubled the recipe for the marinade.

I used both the minced garlic and the powdered garlic. Don't use 'Salt Garlic'. And for the 'Lemon Juice' I used 'Real Lemon' in the bottle. 

I used 'Black Pepper', not the white because I like how it crusts. And for the hot sauce I used 'Red Pepper' powder.  The hot pepper boost serves to balances the spices it does not make the meat hot at all..

I used 'Extra Virgin Olive Oil' because it has more flavor.  I wanted to stretch the recipe so I added about 1/3 cup more oil.  

I split marinade up into three plastic zippos, threw a tenderloin in each one.  Marinaded it in the frig, turning the bag over a few times over a 6 hour period.

text:
I have used this same recipe for over 15 years with one change. My recipe calls for a 1/4 cup of mustard. I prefer a grainy dijon but any will work and each will subtly change the marinade's flavor. I have even used horseradish and what a kick that gives. I also will marinade tougher cuts for 12 to 14 hours and the lemon juice makes them very tender. It also works very well as an injection sauce but must be very well blended. JC3

text:
This was great. I used 3 fresh garlic cloves, sirracha sauce and added a little dijon mustard as another reviewr did. I mixed this in my food processor and it gave the marinade a great texture....one that I dont think I could have acheived by just srtiring with a spoon.  I marinated 2 ribeyes for 22 hours. The steaks came out so juicy. I had reserved some of the marinade and heated it up to drizzle on as I served the steak. It was wonderful. This ones a keeper for us!!

city:

country:
None
text:
I decided to try this after seeing some good reviews. It makes quite a bit of marinade, but I did two large flank steaks with it in two separate bags. I followed the directions, except I cut the basil in half as I ran out. I used low-sodium soy sauce, and would definitely suggest that. It is quite salty, from the soy sauce, even using that substitution. I also did add the optional ingredients. At first bite I thought it had a strong taste of the basil, but the more I ate it, the more I liked it. The only downside, is it actually over-tenderized. I never thought that was possible. I broiled my flank steak, as usual, and it was so tender I almost had trouble cutting it. I would definitely use this for a tough, less flavorful, cut of meat as the marinade does have very strong flavor. It would mask a good steak, in my opinion. For some reason, I could see men liking this though.

text:
I've read a lot of reviews were people substituted this or that, well for me, I always try a recipe as written first, before I decide to substitute, add, delete, etc.

There is nothing I would change about this recipe!!  I tried this for the first time on a day I was having my family, and an old Navy buddy who was passing through town, over for grilled steaks and boiled shrimp.  I wanted to do something different with the steaks, and I found this recipe and tried it.  I doubled the recipe because I had 8 steaks, and put them on to marinate about 10:00pm to go on the grill at 4:00pm the next day.

There was not a single bite of steak left on ANYONE's plate, and all were raving about how flavorful and tender the steaks were.  (I use a gas grill) My Navy friend took a photo of the recipe on his way out so he could have it when he got home.  He sent me pictures of the baby back ribs and chicken he was grilling after marinating them in this stuff, and said they both came out fantastic!

So thanks Kookie for sharing this!  It's phenomenal just the way it is, and I really can't picture myself seasoning a steak any other way anymore.  Heck, I may even marinate some rib eyes just to see how great it will make them taste!

SOPHIEFRISE

country:

text:
I have made this 2 times already.  The first was on steak, then the second was on pork chops.  For a 3rd time this month, I am using it once again on chicken.  

My family loves this recipe and is a keeper.  Minor changes : (1)I don't blend it, I just use a whisk and whisk it really good before I put it in a ziplock bag. (2)I do use the mince garlic, but it is fresh. We love garlic, so the more the merrier and (3) instead of 1 1/2 tablespoons of parsley, I just use 1 tablespoons since parsley can be strong. 

This recipe is a hit. Even with folks that don't care too much for the ingredients, but together and after grilled, they are amazing. I recommend everyone trying this.
Review:
Rating:
5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm going through and reviewing all the recipes I have tried and I can say I like this one.  I use far less olive oil because I really don't see the need.  I also use less lemon juice because it will "cook" the meat.  Not necessary to use only white pepper so I just used good old fashion fresh cracked black pepper (yumm).  Marinate with soy sauce, olive oil (2 tbsp), splash of lemon juice, Worcestershire, minced garlic, parsley and tsp cracked pepper.  NO NEED to blend in blender.  Just throw in a non-reactive bowl or baggie (my choice)  Marinate for at least 2 hours.  Take the out of baggie toss on grill as you normally would and they come out quite nice.

Doubled the recipe, but only used enough lemon juice for a single batch (Only had 2 lemons, and it wasn't enough, apparently).  Overall, it was very good!
UPDATE: I made it exactly as written, using a large pack of stewing beef that I softened with my meat tenderizer.  I poured the marinade over it & let it sit for about 30 min.  Then I made Shish-Kebabs with it.  I ised 1 large pack of stewing beef, 1 red pepper, 1 green pepper, and 1 red onion.  It made 22 delicious shish-kebabs!!

We've been using this marinade for YEARS! We don't add the hot pepper sauce. 

We use it on chicken! We marinade boneless, skinless chicken breasts and grill them on the bbq pit. We also take what's left of the marinade and boil it down on the stove, skimming off any fat off the top, and serve it as an au jus on the side. 

It's tangy and salty. We love it!

userID:
5397908
Display Name:
testekleez
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the marinade exactly as instructed with the optional ingredients added and yes I used a blender (is it really that big a deal to blend it).   I marinated one 1.25 inch t-bone I bought from Publix (which are pretty good quality as far as grocery store steaks go) in a sealed container for almost 2 hours.  Then I rinsed off (yes rinsed off) the marinade from the meat and patted the steak dry with paper towels. Then I put approximately 1/4 teaspoon of kosher salt on each side and about a 1/2 teaspoon of black pepper on both sides and finally, liberal amounts of garlic powder infused with parsley on both sides.  Then I let the steak sit at room temp for a little over half an hour and broiled for 7 minutes a side for medium rare and it was outstanding! The marinade adds just a subtle hint of flavor that brings out the beef flavor nicely. No steak sauce needed at all.   This was SLIGHTLY better than my normal routine which is just using Moore's marinade for a half hour meat-bath prior to seasoning and cooking.  All in all this recipe is a winner!   I wouldn't marinate it for a long time like many posters have done, unless it was a sorry piece of meat.
Review:

userID:
3802088
Display Name:
CharlotteMay

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/231820.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great marinade.  I omitted the white pepper by mistake, and the dried minced garlic because I was concerned it would put the garlic flavor over the top.  I cut the recipe down for one steak.  I didn't blend it.  Just combined the ingredients in a large ziplock bag.  I marinated a ribeye steak for just over an hour, and loved the result! I think it would have been ok after all with the minced garlic, but hubby said he liked it just as it was, without the pepper and minced garlic.  The flavors were balanced perfectly, and the marinade didn't overpower the meat.  I probably wouldn't want to marinate meat for more than a couple hours, or I think you'd lose the taste of the meat.  All in all, a great recipe, and I think this is going to be my standard marinade recipe.  Thanks for sharing your secret with the rest of us!

userID:
10763016
Display Name:
David Stevens
isPro:

15

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2165547.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This s a great recipe. This is the basis for a quik marinade in most my cooking. Reading the recipe only shown what I've done but never actually wrote down. :) I'm big into going threw the cuboards and adding what I find that will work well together and I usually have all these ingredients. I usually add a litle bit of brown sugar and/or paprika to help the outside of my meats get that nice texture when flavoring. I notice reviews that have few stars saying why ruin steaks. And I agree, if you are cooking a steak to eat it as is, but if your ooking steak to add to salad, stir fry, soup, rice and beans, etc, you want to add some flavor and depth and this type of marinade does just that. I stick with as much fresh as I can get or that I at least have in my pantry. Fresh garlic is a must, and fresh lemon juice with some of the peel grated up helps this marinade really take shape and add freshness to it. Something you will never get in a container. Ever try jarred minced garlic? the stuff that looks fresh in oil or water or what ever it's kept in. Has the taste of garlic but it's bitter and missing the depth, and full experience. It's non sense! Anyways I'm done rambling thought I'd share some knowledge :)

text:
In general I like the marinade, but I think there are a few things that could be improved. I used vegetable oil instead of olive oil, I think this is better for bringing out other flavors in the marinade. I used 4 cloves minced garlic, 1 teaspoon of gochujang (you can also use sriracha for something milder). I also added a teaspoon of grated fresh ginger, 1 tbsp of honey, and sliced green onions. I did not use parsley or basil. Whisked the marinade instead of blending.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2014-11-06T19:37:19.773
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
14592991
Display Name:
bschall
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1635791.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was looking for a marinade to use with some top sirloins I had to make a steak salad. I used this recipe with great success. I added all the ingredients but hot sauce and minced garlic, but I changed the amounts of many ingredients after looking at the list. To marinate just a few small steaks it would make way too much marinade, and I thought the amounts were a little off. I halved the soy sauce and olive oil. I used only about a teaspoon of bottled lemon juice, same amount worchestershire, same amount garlic, about 1 t basil, and 1 t parsley, and a dash of pepper. I didn't blend, just added to the bag my steaks were in and let it marinate for 2 1/2-3 hours, then grilled on the BBQ. The marinade was a great way to make a cheap cut of steak taste great. I think my tweaking and reduced marinating time made the flavor perfect and not overpowering. It worked perfectly in the salad. I won't use this for nice cuts (all those need is salt) but it will be my go-to for the tougher and less-expensive cuts from now on.

userID:
7346910
Display Name:
Morrigan
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give this recipe 4 stars because like others have said, it needs some changes.  The first time I made it exactly as written, except with fresh basil and fresh garlic (I always use fresh when I can) and found the basil and soy sauce over-powering.  It was too salty!  The second time, I omitted the soy sauce completely and reduced the basil - it was still not quite there.  Now I substitute balsamic vinegar (1/8 of a cup) instead of any soy sauce.  I also add 1 tsp. white pepper, 1 tsp. mustard powder, 5 cloves of fresh garlic, 1 tbsp Frank's Red Hot (I like a bit of heat) and 2 tbsp. Montreal steak spice - I know, I shouldn't have to add the Montreal steak spice, but with it actually seems to really enhance all the other flavors and make a good thing even better.  I use the juice of one lemon and haven't noticed an "off-flavor" as others have put it.  But I personally like lemon and it probably cuts a bit of the salt from the Worcestershire sauce and the Frank's Red Hot. I gave this 4 stars even though I make a lot of changes, because this recipe was the springboard for me to find something that works for me.  I have marinated New York strip steak overnight and they are melt-in-your-mouth tender.  I have done 24 hours and 9 hours and 5 hours - I am in the "longer is better" club because I find the 24 hours to be awesome.  Do the ziplock bag and shake it every 3 hours during the day just to get all the flavors combined.  :D

This is truly the "Best Steak Marinade" ever! My husband recently got dentures and had such difficulties adjusting to them. I used this marinade recipe (substituting lemon juice with 1/3 C of wine, and eliminating the hot pepper sauce) on a rib-eye steak. I pricked the meat with a large fork, poured on a portion of the marinade over the steak and marinated the meat for about 3 hours. He really eat up his steak!!! Now I keep this marinade in the fridge for the next time I use it on steak. Thanks, Kookie, for sharing this recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been using a similar recipe for years:   terriyaki or low sodium soy sauce; olive oil, 1 cup red wine (Merlot/Cab Sauv, etc), Worcs. Sauce, crushed garlic, 1-2 T of Moore's Seasoning; prepare the beef first by rubbing in a mixture of salt, fresh ground black pepper, dill seed, coriander seed, paprika, garlic; marinate for 1-8 hours; prepare the beef/steak and reserve the marinade; sautee fresh mushrooms & garlic in 1-2 T olive oil, add marinade; reduce heat and simmer for 10-15 minutes until rendered and consistency is just right!  Serve Steak w/ Mushrooms in Wine Sauce.   Yum!  (For chicken or pork, I use a white wine - Chardonnay, etc) with everything else the same.

Made two rib eye steaks (big ones) with this marinade last night and it was the best steak I have ever made. I left out the hot sauce (not a fan) and lemon juice (on accident) and it was still fantastic. I pan seared the steaks in a cast iron skillet for about 6 minutes each side and then popped it in the oven for another 10 min to finish it off. Perfection! And made delicious cold leftovers also! I keep sneaking bites all day.

text:
Wow...  Wow...  Referencing an old Saturday Night Live bit... "it's (the steaks)  like butter"..   I had out of town guests come sorta unexpectedly to help us out w/car issues.  Since our local grocery store had a steal of a sale on Tbones, that's what I decided to serve.  Why marinade Tbones?  Cuz my sister-in-law insisted.  Boy am I glad she did!   I made this marinade and used it on the Tbones and ohmygawd... I could tell that pretty much everyone wanted to lick their plates!   My changes?  Well, I used fresh parsley, basil and garlic cuz I had them and since I had only half the Worchestersire sauce (how'd that happen?) I just added extra soy sauce and put in about 1 Tbsp of tomato paste substitute the missing Worch.  Anyway, yes, this is a keeper of a recipe - THANK YOU for being willing to share it with us when you know others are bound to take the credit for you/your family's recipe.  I promise to give credit where it's due - it's only fair consider what you shared with us.  EVERYONE should try this!  It is EXCELLENT!  No one touched the bottled steak sauces that usually get poured on.  A couple people added a little salt, other than that, they ate them as I served them off of the grill.  Again, thank you Kookie!!!  I'm going to try it with burgers, I'm sure it will work it's magic there, too!   Thanks again, Becky

text:
My parents have been making a very similar marinade as long as I can remember, and you're right - it's wonderfu!  My family's version adds about 4TB of brown sugar and 1/2 tsp of dry mustard - otherwise, it's identical.  The brown sugar makes for nice carmelization when the meat is grilled or broiled. We also usually use fresh garlic, but the nice thing about this recipe is it's pretty forgiving.  Thanks for posting!

text:
A flavorful and delicious marinade! It's perfect as is, no changes needed, unless you want to (a) save a step and skip the blender AND (b) use fresh minced garlic instead of garlic powder. You can mix all the ingredients together in a Ziploc bag and put the steaks inside. A wonderful and super easy recipe - you probably already have all of the ingredients on hand in your kitchen! This is our family's tried and true marinade for beef and chicken.

text:
I have made this twice.  The first time I did NOT follow the directions that said to put it through a blender or processor.  But I did follow the advice from Christie suggesting to sprinkle some sugar on the steaks before cooking.  That made all the difference for us.  We are a little sweet oriented.  The second time, I put the ingredients through the blender first.  Wow!  That was great.  Nice, smooth sauce.  And adding the sugar at the end made these the best steaks I've ever put on the grill.

text:
Not to pop anyone's bubble but I've been making this for 20 plus years.  I have never blended it.  I put it in a quart jar and shake it up, pour what I need to cover meat I've put in a ziplock bag, and saved what's left in the fridge until the next time.  I also add about 3 tablespoons brown sugar.  It's an excellent marinade for beef, pork and chicken!!

text:
Absolutely AMAZING! We buy ribeyes, Deni them front and back, pour the marinade into a pan and let them soak for 5-8 hours. Best steaks ever!! We loved the marinade so much, I take the remaining marinade, reducing it with 1 tbsp of sugar: bring to a quick boil (kill bacteria from the raw meat) them immediately keep stiring it with a whisk on low heat.. Perfect steak sauce as well. Add a dash of corn starch to make it thicker if desired.

This is a very good recipe for select steaks.  I definitely would not use it on choice or prime meat(kosher salt and pepper only). If you do use this marinade, please don't waste it afterward.  Add simmered to mushrooms and maybe onions as an excellent topping or side dish to your meal.

country:

text:
Second time making this. Excellent marinade, followed Diyeanna's lead and did mushrooms with the sauce too. I personally found it a touch salty so use light or sodium-reduced soy sauce to tone the salt down a bit. I also used half onion half garlic powder instead of the full garlic powder amount and I used my food processor to blend it (didn't the first time). It does make it nice and thick and I found the flavours blended better but that's just my two cents!!
Quick edit: For the love of steak, make sure it is PATTED DRY before grilling/cooking it! Taking it out and throwing it on the grill without patting it down makes it taste very off.

text:
This is the fourth time I made this marinade and I think it's the best.  You will get a lot of marinade if you follow the recipe so if you plan on making only two steaks like I do, you may want to cut the ingredients in half.  I used black pepper from my grinder, low sodium soy sauce and did not add cayenne.  I usually marinate for 5 hours and then grill.  This marinade will make "cheaper" steaks taste great.  Thanks to this marinade I can make steak that tastes better than any steakhouse steak!!  I will use only this recipe from now on.

text:
I used this to marinade beef kebabs for a party based on it's reviews.  This was WONDERFUL!!!  I used ribeye for the kebab meat and it was OUTstanding!  I marinaded the meat overnight and I found it  touch too salty for my taste (and I'm a salty kind of guy) but I also don't use low-sodium soy sauce.  I might buy some to have on hand for this marinade or maybe half my soy sauce and use rice wine in stead (not rice wine vinegar for anyone who is reading this and it sounds good).  Rice wine is a totally different product - no salt, about 14% alcohol called Shaoxing and it's darn hard to find.  Go to the asian grocery and ask.

city:

country:
None
text:
Tried it, LOVED it! I did substitute a few things. I used a large portion of rosemary with a dash of basil, and went easy on the lemon juice as the ribeye's I had were top quality and did not need much tenderizing. Smelled good enough when it hit the grill to pull several of my neighbors out to inquire. I wound up sharing out a few tastes and now we've a impromptu friends an neighbor's BBQ in a few days. Use sense with this recipe, if you don't like strong herb flavor's go easy on those, adjust the acids to suit your quality of meat (cheap needs the full amount). This is a great starter marinade to branch out from as you get comfortable an start to tweak.

text:
This was pretty darn good!  We had a very cheap cut of steak.  I was looking for a way for it not to be as tough as it normally is. Here's what I did.  Covered it in kosher salt for 1 1/2 hr.  Washed off the salt.  Marinated in this mixture for a couple of hours in the fridge.  Then, took it out and let it warm up to room temperature and grilled.  What a difference!

text:
I reviewed this recipe 5-6 mos. ago and gave it 4 stars, but since then, I don't think I've prepared steak (read: ribeye) any other way, so an upgrade to 5 stars is really necessary!  This really IS "the best" marinade ever -- as long as you include all ingredients, including the hot sauce (this is really "the secret") AND put it all in the blender.  Use 1/2 - 3/4 for the marinade and reserve the rest for sauce.   Please forget the so-called "purists" who have reviewed this with disdain and low scores.   Look -- steak is great in many different ways.  If you're not a marinade type, you have no business here.

text:
This is almost identical to a recipe that I developed back in the 1970's.  The original recipe I based it on was from a recipe book that came with a Big Boy BBQ grill my parents bought back in the late '50's.  It is a really great marinade, and I have used it on beef, chicken and lamb, and it works great on all of them.  Try it with fresh garlic and parsley!  I sometimes sub Kikkoman terriyaki sauce instead of soy, and that is good, also.  GREAT marinade for kebobs!

userID:
1916615
Display Name:
Trouble In The Kitchen
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Kookie, you definately deserve 5 stars for this concoction! This has been my favorite steak marinade for about 2 years now. I've used it on top sirloin, strip loin, and even my expensive ribeye steaks, and it has turned out amazing every time. I change it up a bit depending on what I have on hand, I have made it exactly as written and with various changes. Today it was strip loin steaks. I left out the lemon juice because I wanted to marinate all day (acidic ingedients like lemon can toughen meat after about 2 hours. Do try it with the Lemon though, its fabulous!). Instead I added about a teaspoon or so of dijon mustard. I used all fresh herbs and garlic, frank's red-hot, marinated about 10 hours and then threw em on the grill. Mmmmmmm...so delicious! Thank you so much for sharing this Kookie!

text:
I give this recipe 5 stars based on my modifications.  First of all, I was just cooking for my fiancé and me, so I halved the recipe.  In place of the garlic powder and minced garlic, I used one clove of chopped fresh garlic.  I used fresh basil (about 4 leaves chopped) instead of dried and I reduced the amount of oil and lemon, although not by much.  I also added red chili flakes instead of hot pepper sauce.  I marinated overnight and this is similar to a korean bbq type of marinade but not as sweet.  Regardless, it was DELICIOUS!  My fiancé loved it too and he's a very cultured food man :)

Display Name:
bhuwe

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My entire family LOVES this marinade.  My son - who doesn't like steak otherwise - loves this marinade.  Depending on what I have in the house, I've made it with and without the lemon, substituted teriyaki sauce for part of the soy when I ran out, used fresh garlic instead of powder - they still all love it!  I don't bother with the blender - that's just one more thing to clean.  I mix all the ingredients in a very large measuring cup and then pour them over the steaks.  Also - I boil the marinade afterwards, adding a cup of water with a tbs of flour in it to thicken it, and make a sauce/gravy to use over the steak, rice, and or anything else.   My kids literally lick their spoons !

text:
Outstanding steak marinade! I almost psyched myself out because I was using T-Bones, and I usually don't marinate them because they are so nice to begin with. But I'm so glad I did! I made the recipe exactly as stated, minus the Worcestershire sauce because I didn't have any. I subbed A-1 instead. I also left out the garlic powder and used 1.5 Tbsp of minced garlic instead. I marinated the T-Bones overnight, then pan fried them today. Fabulous! This is definitely going to be my go to marinade from now on!

This marinade was fantastic.  I was a little skeptical at first but it turned out wonderfully.  I did however have to make some adjustments due to lack of a couple of items.  Instead of parsley and basil, I used 3 tablespoons of Italian Seasoning, and a dash of sage.  I also added one clove of fresh garlic.  Everyone raved about the flavor of the steaks.  I normally let them marinate overnight was behind schedule, so they only got about 3 hours of marinating in and still turned out delicious.  I will be using this marinade over and over.

text:
I use a similar recipe learned from chefs on cape cod. This is simpler and fantastic on Rib Eye.  1/4 cup or equal parts of Red Baslamic vinegar, Worcestershire sauce, Soy Sauce and Ken's Light Ceasar Salad Dressing.  ( the salad dressing has oil and lots of black pepper). Poke holes in steak with fork. Just 20 - 60 minutes in refrig is enough.

text:
MMMMMM! This really is the best steak marinade in existence! I'm thoroughly impressed with how tasty and easy it is to make. I didn't have any garlic powder/dried garlic, so I just threw in a coarsely minced large clove into the blender. Also subbed fresh basil for dried. Oh, and I scaled it down to 2 servings to marinate a single 3/4 lb grass-fed porterhouse steak--the perfect amount for an awesome steak.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really enjoy this recipe a lot (including for tuna steaks).  One of the changes I did make was to substitute cayenne pepper for white pepper, since I have found that cayenne pepper goes wonderful with steaks.  Also, I have found one of the best ways to cook with this marinade is to sear the steaks at high heat (either pan or grill), then place them in a glass container, pour the marinade on them, and cook in the oven until they are done to your liking.  This cooking style is a variation of the most common restaurant style in which an iron skillet is used to sear them and then bake them.  My wife doesn't normally like steak, but she loves this recipe.  Thanks for sharing your family's work with us.

text:
Excellent marinade. Halved the recipe & replaced garlic powder with 3 very large garlic cloves. Put all in a ziploc bag with 2 ribeye steaks, only could marinade for 2 hours but was enough time for it to do its magic and transform an ordinary steak into... Well, you will just have to try this yourself. Sliced 8 oz. mushrooms, added to excess marinade and sauteed, then topped this over the steaks. The last time I had a steak this good was with an aged steak. Hope this helps in your  decision making.

text:
i should have marinated longer, it really was delicious though. I had rib eye, put cast iron skillet in ovet at 500 degrees for 20 min, then i took skillet out of oven, placed over high heat on oven, seared steaks without moving, 3 min each side, then threw oven on broil and did 3 min each side on broil, about 6 inches from flame. after that, i let stand 5 minutes so juices absorb. came out great, making again soon and will marinate more than 30 minutes this time.

This is a superb marinade, without question.    I used fresh basil and parsley from my garden instead of dried.  I didn't blend the ingredients, and only marinated the meat for about two hours. Great and easy.  I blended it per the directions, but i can't see why it was necessary unless you just like washing oil out of a blender.  Marinated them overnight and they turned out great.  Squeeze the lemon juice fresh, it's worth it.

userID:
20976
Display Name:
Norma June Penny
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
25
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3806008.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave this a 4 star rating because (a) I've never used a marinade before and have no idea if it is the best marinade in existence and (b) I did tweak it a little bit:    I made it according to the recipe but reduced it for 2 people.  I always read the reviews before trying a recipe and so with this recipe I took some reviewers' advice and added some Dijon mustard (Hellmann's squeeze) and about 1 tbsp. of brown sugar.  It was really good, thank you for sharing your recipe.  My husband really liked it and so did I ... and we're extremely fussy.  LOL  I let it sit in a Ziploc bag for over 30 hours (because we couldn't cook it and it had to wait until the next night but it was great for having to sit that long in the marinade).  I tossed it on my barbecue.  I also tenderized it prior to putting it in the marinade in the bag by hitting it with a jar of pickles (LOL ... don't have a meat tenderizer hammer thingy). Then when it was in the bag along with the marinade I pounded it again.  It really was tender (it was a very large sirloin tip steak that was on sale) and I didn't need any A-1 Steak Sauce like I normally do.  I served it with baked potatoes and garlic sauteed Swiss chard in EVOO (extra virgin olive oil).  I'll make this again and I've printed it out and it's going in my Tried & True Recipe Book.

text:
Another five star review.  I used this marinade on sirloin steaks for the 4th of July barbecue.  The men raved about the steaks. (I love it when that happens!) :o)  I used about 5 large cloves of fresh pressed garlic in place of the powder, omitted the optional hot pepper and dried garlic, and did not blend the mixture. Just threw the steaks and marinade into a freezer bag and froze them until I needed them.  They were superb!!  Thanks for a definite winner!

text:
This came out very flavorful and it was very easy! A couple of lessons learned: 1) I think this is definitely a beef-oriented marinade. I tried it on pork and the flavor was definitely "beef." 2) Don't salt the meat with this marinade. Came out wayyyyy too salty. I liked that I didn't have to marinade for very long (maybe 2 hours) to get a good flavor from this recipe.

text:
I'm not sure about "Best In Existence" -  I'll get back to you when I've tried all the others.  This one, however, is sure to rank high for any competition that factors in cost,  simplicity, availability of ingredients in an average kitchen and the flavor of the ultimate result.  It didn't overpower the steak's flavor, but complimented it.  On the grill, it charred a little around the outside of a thin vein of fat - keeping the flavor in.    Once on the grill, I poured the remaining marinade on top and let it soak into the meat as it cooked.    I'll certainly be using this one again.

I cut the soy to 1/4 cup. Cut the Worcestershire to 1/8 cup.  I added 1/4 cup good balsamic vinegar and 1 heaping teaspoon Dijon mustard. Used pressed fresh garlic rather than garlic powder. Go easy on the white pepper, I used fresh ground black pepper. Just hand mix in a bowl.  Now, its the Best Steak Marinade in Existence. Try it.

text:
My wife and I have made this several times leaving out the hot pepper sauce  and the minced garlic.

We let it marinate for anywhere between 24 and 72 hours.

When we cook it in a pan on the stove (yes, I hear you all gasping -- this is how we have to do it right now!), we pour the marinade in the pan and cook the steaks in that.

We have never found a better marinade.

I have had nearly the same exact recipe for over forty years. Not sure if it was printed somewhere at some time or not. Anyway, I use only fresh garlic and I omit the heat and the basil. No blending necessary. Best on flank steak and when meat is marinated overnight. Double the marinade and reserve some to reheat as an au jus. Cook meat to medium rare and slice thin.

text:
In love with this recipe.  I used two NY Strips, allowed to marinate 24 hours, and could really taste to flavors.  Whisked in a bowl because I was too lazy to clean a blender or processor after.  When I make a few mason jars for friends, I'll probably blend.  Used fresh parsley, basil, and 3 cloves of garlic instead of dried herbs.  Since this was my first time making it, and it turned out superb, I'll probably stick to the fresh (unless I'm too lazy to go to the store).    
I don't care what people say about good steak and only salt and pepper........this marinade is far superior to the just salt and pepper.  :P  Thanks for the recipe.  Next test.....use on my dad.

text:
I made this marinade pretty much as written, but did make a few minor changes based on others comments:  I used 1 Tablespoon of lime juice (didn't have any lemons on hand) and 2 Tablespoons of balsamic vinegar in place of the 1/3 CUP of fresh lemon juice.  I also used 2 Tablespoons of minced garlic and left out the garlic powder.  Otherwise, made exactly as written (including using the blender).  It turned out great after marinating the steaks for about 4 hours.  I used the leftover marinade to sauté some fresh mushrooms and onions and they were also delicious.  Thank you---will be making this again!

Me and the fam really like this marinade. I've made it several times already. First time making I used a blender but every time since I've just mixed the ingredients together and poured over meat. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not sure if it's the *best* in existence but it's pretty good. Used 2 New York strip steaks and halved the recipe. I couldn't find any white pepper so I just used the regular black pepper I had. If I use this marinade again, I'd probably use more of the soy and pepper sauces, more pepper, and a little less lemon juice. I let the steaks sit in the marinade about 2-3 hours before throwing them on the grill. They were really tender and the excess marinade made a nice crust on the edges. 9/10, would use again.

Edit: Made this again, realized I'd forgotten to add the Worcestershire sauce last time.  I made the full recipe this time instead of half. Would still use more pepper next time. I didn't use a blender either time, just dumped everything in a zip top bag and mixed it together like that.  

Final say: 9.75/10. I'd still make some personal taste adjustments but if you actually use the Worcestershire sauce like the recipe says to, it does turn out better and you can use the full amount of lemon juice the recipe calls for.

Better than 5 STARS!!!  I use this recipe once a week and it is fantastic...exactly as written...no changes needed.  My one tweak is that I put the steaks in a Ziploc Bag and pour the marinade in with them.  I usually try to let marinade for at least a few hours.  I also pull them from the fridge 30 minutes prior to grilling to allow the steaks to come to room temperature ~  They are fantastic!!!  Won't use any other marinade.

text:
As others have said, not sure if this is the best, but it is delicious! My hubs deemed it "restaurant quality" tonight. I made it as written, except: omitted dried garlic & cut down olive oil. I did use the blender -- keep in mind, if your marinade is smooth, no "burnt bits" from the grill. I popped it in a bag with juicy filets. Let it marinate in the fridge for 3 hours. 1/2 hour prior to grilling, I drained marinade over sliced portabellas, and while steaks were resting, I simmered the 'shrooms. Delightful!

It isn't inedible or anything, but it did absolutely nothing for my NY strips. I am wanting a far deeper flavor without tasting like teriyaki. These babies soaked for 8 hours; and two things were evident: The Asian flavor was off-putting, and the other flavors weren't strong enough to soak into the steak. In the future, I will stick to a mustard/melted butter combo with steak salts. If you do like the flavor, I suggest letting it sit for 24 hours in it, to maybe pull in the flavor better.

userID:
14090840
Display Name:
Mike Farrace
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic recipe. The steaks were amazing and there was practically a fist fight over the au jus. Adding basil gives it an unusual but very tasty fresh zing, and blending the mixture for 30 seconds really makes all the ingredients available to the meat. I used a half-dozen garlic cloves instead of the powder, black pepper instead of white, a 50/50 mix of fresh lemon and bottled lime because I didn't have enough lemons. I also used a basil paste and only had about half the specified amount of Worcestershire sauce. I then salted and peppered four 1.25" NY steaks, rubbed in some olive oil and then put the steaks in a 1 gallon ziplock and marinated for about one hour at room temperature. Best one-hour marinade I can remember. I highly recommend it!

Didn't have garlic pwd so I used chopped garlic and I am ashamed to say I didn't have dried basil either but I did have chopped fresh basil  paste  so I cut that down to 1 Tbsp.
Thank you Kookie for sharing this awesome marinade.

Tried this last night on Prime Sirloin Tips.  The hubby is a steak purist and does not believe in putting anything on a steak other than salt and pepper.  I marinated half of the tips and he did his salt and pepper on the other half, and what can I say?  This marinade won, hands down and he is now a convert!  The marinated steak was so much more moist and juicy, not to mention extremely tasty and delicious.  This is our new "go to" marinade for our steaks.

This really is an awesome marinade.  I skip the parsley and the garlic powder and only use fresh basil and freshly grated garlic. It makes it taste so much better.  I haven't used another marinade since I found this one last summer.  I just mix everything in a gallon size zip lock bag, squeeze it all together to mix and add the meat.  It's really one of the best marinades I've ever tried.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1073055.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's tangy with a little bit of sneaky spiciness, and it works well on venison steaks! I had no lemons, so I used red wine vinegar instead. I also used red pepper instead of white, and opted to squeeze a little sriracha into the mix. I let the meat bathe in the marinade for ~6 hours, then grilled it over charcoal for ~5 minutes each side (to medium rare). I made a sauce from the left over marinade by simmering it in a sauce pan for a few minutes. It was great drizzled over the venison cut, which I arranged on a bed of wild rice... So fancy... So 
delicious. :)

This is now the only way I prepare my steaks, except for one change: cut the quantity of lemon in half, which from my measurements means using half of one average size lemon. Also, keep in mind that the brand of soy sauce used matters, as different brands are saltier than others.

userID:
12076483
Display Name:
ausador
isPro:

1

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fairly good marinade but watch the time allowed in the fridge. The "Up to 8 hours" is way too long and makes the flavor far too strong.

I would limit the marinade time to about 3 hours for the best results, at least if you want to taste the steak at all. Otherwise the only flavor present will be the marinade seasoning, which is pretty potent.

When used for grilling it does help the steak take a nice "semi-blackened" color quickly without requiring overcooking and excessive temperature. While I do like this recipe as an addition to my reportoire of marinades it is by no means the "Best Marinade In Existence" in my own humble opinion.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

7751509
Display Name:
JoelKateLazerKitchen!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The husband and I loved this marinade!  I encourage every steak lover to try it and adjust it to your personal taste.  We love both rubs and marinades and we want to taste the meat, not just the seasoning.  We didn't blend it (just hand chopped) and marinated our ribeyes for 2 1/2 hours.  If they had sat for much longer, it would have been too much.  I could understand why some reviews said it was too overpowering if they read the recipe as 'marinate for 8 hrs' instead of UP TO 8 hrs.  We don't eat red meat very often but this recipe makes it impossible to stay away.  We're making it again tonight!

I wish i could give this more than 5 stars. Omg so good! I didnt add the hot pepper sauce but i did add about a tsp of minced garlic. Marinated 2 steaks that are about 1" thick 6 hours and popped them under the broiler after pouring a bit of marinade on top 5 minutes. Love it. Great job.

region:

country:

text:
Gave this a 4 based only on the flavour - I didn't really use it with intentions to tenderize meat - so I can't give it a 5 because I don't know how tender it will make a steak (but I intend to find out).  I thought the flavour of this was really great and it was easy because I had all the ingredients on hand already. I didn't find the taste was offputting like some other ratings said it was.  I also didn't puree the ingredients  - just because I didn't feel like dirtying more dishes! I cut the recipe in half and used 3 minced garlic cloves in place of the garlic powder and dried minced garlic. Had some sirloin steaks in the fridge and felt like trying a marinade so I whipped this together and marinated for only an hour - the flavour was really great after an hour but the marinade didn't have time to work yet (my own fault for not leaving it longer).  I am looking forward to trying this again on a more tough peace of meat for a much longer time period. The only thing I would change would be to add some salt - but I'm usually heavy handed with the salt anyway.  Thanks for a great recipe Kookie!

text:
Needed to rate this.  Made it as is.  I suggest you do this and make changes, if you feel it necessary, according to your own personal preference. 

Absolutely need to blend the ingredients.  It makes a BIG difference.  The ingredients can blend together.  I used my immersion blender - made the job simple.  And yes - it looks off but it'll be ok.  Once you grill it - you'll be left with a piece of meat that will look and taste beautiful.

I made it once in the morning to serve it that evening, once the day before I served it and once I froze it in the marinade.  They all pretty much tasted the same.  So I would say whatever is convenient. 

Also, I didn't feel the need to season my steak at the table - which is a bonus for me.

Thank you soooo much.

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2012-12-20T04:27:16.89

userID:
8467227
Display Name:
Sue
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Four stars as written, five with a few tweaks.  I cut the Worcestershire sauce amount in half, I use low sodium soy sauce, I skip the garlic powder and dried minced garlic and use 3-4 cloves of fresh garlic that I mince instead, and I finely chop some onion to add. I also cut the lemon juice down to 1 Tablespoon. Don't fuss about finding or using white pepper. If you have black (or a melange like me that I freshly grind) that will work great as well. I don't bother putting all this in the blender - it's not really necessary. It simply all goes into a zip-lock bag, in goes the meat and it all goes in the fridge  for at least two hours. It gives a great flavor to the meat and it grills up tender, delicious and juicy every time!

text:
My husband just came home from an exhausting four day scuba diving trip and I prepared this marinade as a "welcome home honey dinner." I used fresh garlic and low sodium soy and did everything else as suggested EXCEPT I didn't blend I just added all of the ingredients in a ziploc bag. I used fresh chopped garlic and kept everything else the same.  My husband could not stop raving about how tender and tasty the steaks were (I used flank steak boneless ribs)... I pan fried the steaks in 2 TBS of olive oil and then added fresh mushrooms, butter and a TBS of cornstarch with the remaining marinade. We will definitely be using this recipe again. I did find it on the saltier side (reason for four stars) but my extremely picky husband loved it and that is all that mattered to me.  He will definitely remember this "welcome home honey dinner" which I will be preparing again very soon OR maybe it will be a traditional meal for those times I welcome him home. We'll see...

text:
I made this marinade yesterday afternoon and put a really tough cut of steak in it for about 24 hrs. Wellll.... my boyfriend ended up making shish kabob out of it on the grill and it was honestly the most tender, succelent, flavorful steak I've ever eaten!!! We both like our steak well done but my parents don't.... They went back for more and more and more! My mom couldn't stop talking about the flavor and how tender it was! The steak was such a tough cut to begin with, how it got that tender while being well done is beyond me. Amazing!

The only thing I did different was use lemon zest instead of lemon juice, didn't add worchester because I didn't have any (will next time) and put about  1 1/2 tblsp of dijon mustard in it. SOOOOO GOOD!! :)

Awesome!

I marinated two venison backstraps last night and it came out just awesome! I only had about 1 TBL of basil, and I added in some black pepper. I was too lazy to blend it, so it all just went in a ziplock bag and left on the counter for about an hour. After the venison had marinated and was on the grill, I took the left over juice and poured it into a foil pack of mushrooms that went on the grill too. They came out just delicious.

I think in the future I might cut down the oil a bit. Will DEFINITELY use again!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe for a thick shoulder steak. Didn't have garlic powder, lemons, or white pepper so I substituted 3 large cloves of garlic (Italian household...need lots of garlic), fresh lime juice, and black pepper. I also added in a little dried oregano and omitted the pepper sauce. I thought 8 hours of marinating was too short, especially for a thick cut, so I went up to 20 hours. After taking the steak out of the marinade I boiled the extra for a few minutes so I could use it to baste portabella mushrooms (also grilled). Amazing! The 20 hours was a good choice, and I think it would have been better if I had let it sit for 24, but I was very happy with the result. Even my husband (the grill master in our family) absolutely loved it! I'll be adding this to my recipe book!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
FOR PEOPLE WITH SOY ALLERGIES:

To substitute the 1/3 cup soy sauce called for in the recipe, I used three packets G. Washington's Rich Brown Seasoning & Broth (found in my local Giant's organic section, 1/3 cup water, 1 tsp. balsamic vinegar, 1/2 tsp. dark molasses, and a pinch each of ground ginger, white pepper, and garlic powder. Mixed up these ingredients and microwaved for 1 minute to dissolve; it yielded 1/3 cup 'soy' sauce. Then I continued with the marinade recipe as written. Delicious!!

The soy sauce substitute was taken from Rongway's "Soy Sauce Substitute Recipe" right here on allrecipes - the first ingredient in that recipe is beef bouillon, but read your labels - I've yet to find any flavor standard bouillon that doesn't contain a soy ingredient, so be sure to check out a specialty store or the organic section.

text:
I dont know if this is the best marinade ever (since i haven't tasted them all), but I can definitely say this is the best marinade I have ever used.  The taste permeates the meat and it just wonderfully flavorful. I used this to marinate sirloin steaks and then to marinate T-bone steaks (for the 1st dinner I ever cooked for my boyfriend).  I was so nervous but he really liked it.  Instead of the tsp of dry minced garlic I used one whole garlic clove.  It. Was. Great. I searched and searched for a good recipe that would be worth the time and just decided to go for it....so to all you skeptical people who don't want to waste your time on a marinade that isn't good...TRY THIS!!!!

text:
Doubled the ingredients, 4 large Filet Mignon's, blended ingredients in BlendTec Mixer,(The Secret - we marinaded them for 2 nights turning them every morning and evening), Placed on a Treager Grill using mequite pellets at 375 for 30 minutes, turned over and cooked another 7-10 minutes. The Filet Mignon's were at least 1 3/4 inch thick. The result - PErfection like none other. The filets MELTED in our mouths and no other sauce was necessary. My most sincere compliments to the creator of this recipe. We absolutely love it. Also, using fresh ingredients works best.

I tried it and it had a bit too much garlic flavor for my tastes.  MY TASTES.  This could be because I used a super fine garlic powder or maybe because I am a vampire.  It's all rather subjective, you see. I also found that fresher lemon juice and knowing the basics of how to cook will prevent a tough steak. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/419392.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought the marinade was great. I used it on 2 1/2 pounds of top sirloin. I found the amount of basil and parsley to be a waste as most of it gets left behind in the bowl and washed down the drain, not to mention the dried herbs absorb the marinade and rob it from the meat. I will use less next time as I don't think 3 Tbs of basil, and 1 1/2 Tbs of parsley is really necessary. I will also reduce the lemon juice to 1/4 cup as it didn't overpower but was on the verge in my opinion. I used Sriracha pepper sauce and left out the additional minced garlic because this sauce contains garlic. I didn't use white pepper as I'm not a fan, instead I used black. It needs a little something, perhaps a little coriander.

text:
The name of this recipe totally fits.  We have been eating cheaper cuts of steak all summer due to the economy and I got to the point where I just could not eat them anymore until this recipe.  I once again bought a cheap sirloin steak on sale.  Followed this recipe exactly and let them marinate for 24 hours in a ziploc bag.  I did flip the bag around from side to side in the fridge a few times so each side was marinated properly.  Grilled them up and I was in steak heaven.  The flavor was fantastic and tender like you would not believe. We talked about those steaks for days!!!

text:
This was wonderful! Bottom round roasts were on sale, so I bought a few and cut them into steaks to try several different marinades. This one had the lowest expectations and turned out to be the best! I am not a huge fan of pepper, but this one had the perfect amount for me.  Hubby loves pepper and says he could taste it and it was the perfect amount.  He would suggest using more, because he is a fanatic, but its not often that he is satisfied with the amount of pepper. He would suggest more to further suit his own tastes, but states it is fabulous as is.  If I were going to change anything, I would add more hot pepper sauce, as I used a cayenne pepper sauce and felt that was more of the pepper flavor I was tasting. Definately taste the basil in it and would like to try with fresh basil. Outstanding! Have been looking for a great marinade to use on steaks that I'm too afraid to ruin with marinade and have decided this couldn't ruin any steak around.  Unbelievable!

text:
Wow, When I fist mixed all ingrediants except the parsley, because I did not have any, I was a little nervous,  because of the amount of Basil the marinade did not look to tasty, even a little scary. When we cooked it on the grill still a little scary because the Basil causes the steak to become very dark. Then I had my 1st bite. That was when the WOW factor came in, I loved it this is a keeper. (I as well did not use a mixer). This recipe is really good, I have always been told that my marinade is the best anyone has had, I'm not so sure anymore. If anyone would like to try another very simple steak marinade that is awesome, all you need is 2 part  Wish Bone Robusto Itlian dressing and 1 part Kikkoman teriyaki marinade. I never measure I just make sure that there is more dressing than merinade. I have made my marinade forever because everyone loves it so much,I'm so glad to finally find another marinade that is very good

This is a very good marinade but I gave it only 4 stars because it simply wasn't what I was looking for and is not necessarily my preference.  Having said that though the flavors were wonderful together and everyone else really like it.  It taste's like an Asian marinade of some sort (Asian BBQ?). However, If I try this again I'll marinade for a little less time because I couldn't really taste the actual beef.  I used sirloin steaks.

text:
The whole family LOVED the taste of this marinade.  I wasn't crazy about the smell when it was all mixed together so I was a little hesitant, but it was very flvorful and yummy.

The only things I did different were....I used bottled lemon juice instead of fresh and I used black pepper instead of white (only because thats what I had available).  Also I didn't put in the blender/mixer.  I just mixed it all up and threw it all in a ziploc bag overnight.

I'll definitely use this recipe again although next time I will buy a less lean/more tender cut of steak (my own fault).  I bought a marinating steak (this is what it said on the package) and it was quite tough.

The first time I used it, I didn't use my blender and it still turned out wonderful. The second and third time, I did and it had a different flavor, but still wonderful. text:
This is one of my favorite marinades for steaks. I make 2-3 batches at once and keep it in a large mason jar in the refrigerator. In my experience, it has kept very well for a few months. I think the longest I kept one was 6 months and it was fine, but I would say that would be the max.

text:
I didn't bother blending this mixture.  I just placed my sirloin steaks in a 9x13 dish and evenly poured it over the meat.  Then turned the meat in the marinade until each piece was covered.  Refrigerated it overnight.  Turned the meat again in the morning.  Then cooked on my traeger at 450° for 5 mins per side.  The meat was not that thick and it came out medium rare.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This marinade was a great change from the way I usually do my steaks. WOW! I had some striploins that unfortunately had some tough areas (can’t see what’s on the inside when buying the large ‘slab’ from Costco...) so the lemon in this marinade helped to tenderize those areas. For those who don’t know already, use a Ziploc bag as as the ‘vessel’ for the meat and marinade, then seal the Ziploc after getting as much air out as possible.I left it in the fridge for about 4hrs, then took it out and let it continue soaking up the juice for another 1.5hrs. BBQ’d them and fed them to my family along with some garlic & parmigiana roasted potatoes and a cucumber salad. HUGE HIT WITH THE MYSELF AND MY KIDS! (Single mom here lol) Definitely will make again

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Overall, this is a very good marinade, but I think many steak eaters don't want an outwardly herby flavor, especially if it masks the natural flavor of the steak.  That's why for me, even though I don't personally mind basil flavor, I did experience an uncomfortable basil aftertaste, which leads me to believe it is overdone in this recipe.  Also, no marinade has to be put through a blender as the flavors of the ingredients will naturally marry while in the fridge (and I think it looks more professional to end up with bits of the ingredients being visual to the eater - I mean, why use parsley if you don't want it to be noticed?).  A whisk in a bowl is quite enough.

userID:

Display Name:
Roslyn Grace
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I will be using this marinade again! My fiance came home the other day from Costco with 4 Steaks. Needless to say, we had steak two days in a row. My first go-around was bad!!!!! I did the typical salt and pepper. In a separate pan, I melted some butter and added, mashed garlic cloves (2), fresh rosemary, fresh parsley, fresh basil, and fresh oregano. I allowed it to basically simmer for about 10 minutes. When it came time to turn my steaks, I poured my butter mixture over top and covered the skillet and cooked another 7 minutes on med-high. WHAT ON EARTH HAPPENED!? NO FLAVOR WHATSOEVER!!!! We were very disappointed!!!!!!

Not to allow defeat, I got on my favorite recipe site and found this marinade. I used all fresh ingredients and followed suggestions of adding 1T Sugar and 1C Beef Stock. I put everything in the blender for about 30 seconds and poured it over top my steaks in a ziplock bag. I only marinaded for 4 hours! And they were very VERY good. 

I would have given 5 stars, but for some reason, part of my steak had NO taste to it. I'm not sure if it's the meat or something I'm doing. I do promise the next time I make this I will redo my review if it comes out better.

text:
I make this recipe just as written, except I use fresh garlic instead of dried. I always blend it . I use either a flank or flat iron steak and prick the steak all over with a fork before covering it with the marinade. After cooking it on the BBQ we let it rest for a few minutes and then cut it thin at an angle. It turns out fabulous and has been a favorite of our family and friends for years. It is in our file of "go-to" recipes.

text:
Just made Marinade for the third time!! ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS!! However, I've not yet made it 100% with all the ingredients. I've never put it in a blender. Just a tightly sealed Tupperware container, added steaks and shook the hell out of it!! :-) First time, I didn't have enough soy sauce. Second time, no Worcestershire sauce and this time I have no lemon juice. For some reason, I keep running out of one or the other ingredients but when it's something you crave, you learn to substitute.  For instance, tonight I had to substitute the lemon juice with white vinegar! :-) Each time it has tasted a slightly bit different but still absolutely the best! Sweet, Garlicky, spicy flavor. Just writing this review has made my mouth water! :-)  Had friends come over last weekend and made it for them. They actually copied the recipe and took it home. They ranted and raved about it being the best steak they had ever ate their entire life. I totally agreed! I'm thinking the next time I might try it over pork chops and just make it a little more spicier and a little less sweeter. or, maybe even just adding some of those ingredients to my favorite barbecue sauce and try it over chicken, with a little honey¿

text:
I bought a cheap pack of sirloins, and threw this marinade together - substituting one citrus for another - lemon for lime - but made it exactly as the recipe called out for 0 blended and all (halved, only two steaks) - and left it in the refrigerator to marinate overnight. 

I then pan seared the sirloins, a minute on each side at high heat, then threw the an into the oven at 500 degrees for five minutes to cook to the perfect medium rare (around 130 degrees internal temp).... 

Seriously. This is the Best. . Marinade. Ever. And a wonderful base to experiment from. 

The marinade and the pan searing made these 3 dollar steaks taste like a high end restaurant quality steak. 

THANK YOU!!!!!!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Seriously, this was amazing! And it’s only the second time I’ve grilled steaks. I was looking for something different and I’ll use this marinade over and  over again. It was easy, fast and so good. I did use the blender and cut the recipe in half as I only had two steaks. I did not use the hot sauce or extra garlic, both optional. Outside of that, I followed the recipe. I marinated them for about 5 1/2 to 6 hours.The meat was 1” thick sirloins and I cooked them to medium plus. And the best part was I didn’t put steak sauce on them. I find that if the steak isn’t flavored to my liking, I’ll use steak sauce. These were a touch of flavor but not over powering. I marinated them for about 5 1/2 to 6 hours.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used fresh garlic instead of powdered, and threw a bit of roasted garlic powder in there (just a pinch).  I whisked it up, and threw it in a bag with the steaks.  Everyone loved it!  I’ve used it several times now, and even marinated lamb chops with it to delicious results!  I was worried about the lemon overpowering the meat, but it didn’t.  The soy gave it a nice salty flavor, but didn’t taste like chinese food (don’t worry I use soy in vegetable marinades all the time, it's a great salt substitute if you balance it with a nice acid like balsamic vinegar or apple cider vinegar, lemon juice etc).  The flavor profile was very mild and didn’t overpower the delicious steaks ?? Happy days ??

text:
This marinade turned out great! I marinated one sirloin steak (about 10oz) which was 1 inch thick at the thickest part. I reduced the measurements to tablespoons/teaspoons keeping the ratios roughly the same. I used bottled lemon juice and left out the white pepper and dried minced garlic. I marinated the steak for about 3 hours at room temperature. I made the steak on the grill and it was so good! None of the flavors were overwhelming. They blended well to give the steak a really nice flavor.

Will definitely make again, skipped the spicy stuff and the blender... still turned out beautifully. Marinated for 8 hours in the fridge then let sit at room temperature for 2 hours before grilling at high temperature. I’d recommend dabbing excess marinade off the steaks before grilling to avoid char, then let rest for 5-10 mins. Couldn’t have turned out better!

I don't believe in universal absolutes with cooking, but this is an easy choice for the best steak marinade that I've ever eaten. text:
Family LOVED this marinade... I put in freezer for a day then defrosted for the next day to cook... Ooo So Perfect... I add about a Tab Spoon of liquid smoke for that smoked grill taste, used Tabasco Sauce & Freash Minced Garlic... I Heated cast iron skillets to cook... Used about Tab Spoon or so of (more if you prefer) Unsalted Butter mixed with (Tab. Spoon or so Olive Oil) also spooned over juices/oil while cooking.... Remember your just lightly frying/cooking & not deep frying so oil is Not Heavy... Cook for about 5-6 min per side....Keep oven on 500 for more cooking if steak is to rare....Luv Luv Luv it..

We were supposed to have grilled it for dinner that night, but we ended up going out for lunch and were still too full to have it for dinner.  So......it marinaded for 3 days lol. I've never marinated a steak before and this recipe has changed my way of thinking.

text:
This is the BEST marinade I've tried. Made this but used Italian Seasoning and black pepper as that's what I had on hand. Put the optional hot sauce but not the minced garlic. Placed all ingredients in a gallon plastic bag and squeezed the bag several times to mix. Placed 4 boneless rib eye steaks in and mixed again. Placed in frig on Saturday morning and didn't cook them until Sunday evening. They were divine! So juicy and the flavor was amazing! Thanks for perfecting this recipe!

text:
I’m perplexed. How is this so highly rated?!? I just ruined a nice ribeye with this recipe. Maybe it’s something to try with a sirloin or flank that’s more tough? Honestly-it’s not that it tastes bad aside from being overly salty and too acidic. It’s that it kills all beef flavor and is incredibly boring on top of it. When I cook a steak, I want to taste steak.  I so wish I’d just sprinkled it with some S&P, spices and seared it in the cast iron as I usually do. Only ate 1/4 of my dinner because this marinade just ruined it. Thank goodness for the baked  potato or I’d be ravenous. NEVER again. Dogs will be happy even if they need to drink 5x the normal amount of water. Really bad marinade IMO.

I'm leaving the leftover steaks to marinade until tomorrow, I think is going to be even better.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Let me put how good this marinade is into perspective. My sister stopped eating steak about 15 years ago. I made top serloins for the family with this marinade, and made a piece of BBQ chicken for her. BUT when I came in from the bbq she said the steaks smelled amazing, and asked to have that instead! I couldn’t believe it! She ate every bite, and went back for more. That’s about the best compliment you can get as a cook, and I owe it to this marinade! 
That being said, I do modify it just a bit.  I use one or two cloves of pressed fresh garlic instead of the dried minced garlic, two table spoons of packed brown sugar for a bit of extra sweetness, and a squeeze of Siracha (because that’s how I roll). Perfect every time! It’s the best for a less fatty cut of beef that needs a little extra flavor, like serloin or flank steak. Thanks for posting it!

text:
I'll DEFINITELY will be using this recipe again as a guide. I of course added some extra tidbits..like a little kosher salt after cleaning the meat and fresh ground black pepper. Too, instead of ground white pepper I used black. As for the soy sauce, I used low sodium. Also, I added about a teaspoon of sugar, dry Italian seasonings 3 cloves of fresh crushed garlic and about 3 dashes of Montreal ?? seasoning...and only one average lemon which was a little less than 1/3 cup per the recipe. Lastly, I marinated the steaks about a 1.5 days. My family and I absolutely ?? this marinade and my children do not normally care for steak unless it's somewhere like Morton's Steakhouse. Which is quite pricey but WELL worth it if you could afford it. Magnific!! Thanks for sharing!!

text:
This came out well, I modified the recipe and only used 1 TB of lemon juice and 3TB of italian seasoning in place of the parsley and basil.  I didn't use the optional ingredients, but did add a few good shakes of chili powder.   I only marinaded 2.5 hours since this was my first go at the recipe, probably doing 8 hours would be better.

For those complaining of bitterness and the like, you really need to wipe the steaks off prior to broiling a marinade like this so spices and herbs don't burn.

text:
This was GOOD. I was honestly a little hesitant to make this as I usually would never marinate steak.. However, the cuts I had on hand were a little tough, so I thought why not! It didn't smell the greatest once the ingredients were whisked together (blender isn't req for this) so i was a little iffy at first. I marinated for 24 hrs in a zip lock and WOW... it turned garbage cuts into something worth talking about. 

- i had a lot of left over marinade as i only had 3 steaks
- blender not req
- definitely use a low sodium soy sauce, or even use less then it calls for

well done!

text:
I made this marinade for a porterhouse steak I was planning to cook on the grill. I made some minor substitutions; used lime juice instead of lemon (because that was what I had in the fridge) and I added 1/2 cup of mesquite marinade to the recipe. I marinaded the steak for 24 hours and cooked it on a charcoal grill until medium rare. I finished the last five minutes cooking with Chef Shamy's Garlic Butter. The steak was one of the best steaks I've eaten in awhile, including steaks from high end restaurants. I will definitely use this recipe next time I cook steaks.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Everyone loved this so I'm making it again now. Compliments steak (eye of round) very well. I  reduced the oil to match the (lite) soy sauce. Trimmed the steaks., then tenderized them a little with a hammer, and using a cutting board, tapped the tip of a knife in the steak all over to make some slits to have the marinade penetrate better. I dipped the steaks in the marinade to coat, then put everything in a bag to marinade. I let it sit up to 1.5 days and it came out great. I think this would work well with pork and plan to try that.

text:
I haven't tried this... YET, but from the ingredients & the reviews I've seen, I can tell you that I would NEVER use this on a 'high-end' steak!
Strips, Rib-Eyes, Fillets, etc. should ONLY have salt, pepper & MAYBE some granulated garlic!
Use it with CHEAPER cuts of beef, that will BENEFIT from its flavor enhancing & tenderizing properties (Flat Iron, Sirloin, London Broil, Kabobs, etc.)!
I WILL be trying this (& editing my review) SOON!!!

None
text:
Absolutely amazing marinade. You'll look at that amount of basil and think "This is way too much basil". While you're putting it in, you'll think "I must have read it wrong. This is way too much basil." When you're about to cook the steaks, you'll think "They are covered in basil. It's just too much." Then you'll eat it, and realize it's not too much basil.

The only change I make is to use about 4 cloves of fresh garlic instead of dried. I've made it half a dozen times and it comes out great every time.
