text:
This is our go-to marinade and we've recommended it to pretty much all of our friends and family. We have a lot of wild meat (moose mainly) and the steaks can be a little tough and gamey. This marinade solves both of those problems and we end up having steak a lot more often. This recipe makes a lot so I usually marinate the meat in as much as I need to, then save the extra to make into a sauce for the meal. We have also used it to marinade meat for home made pho (soup) and I add the extra to the broth. Yum!

text:
I did not have lemon juice, so I subbed red wine vinegar as the acid and it still turned great! I'm sure the lemon juice is even better. I used this on a top sirloin steak I bought on sale. I put a couple tablespoons of butter in a cast iron skillet and seared each side on medium/high heat for about 5 min. on the first side and 3 min. on the second. I poured the melted butter and pan juices over the steak. It came out a perfect Medium. Even my cheaper cut of meat was tender and delicious!

text:
I've made this 4 or 5 times this summer. I thought it might get too salty with all the soy and worcestershire but it's not.  
I started using fresh herbs, basil, rosemary, and italian parsley instead of the dry herbs and it makes it even better. Don't skimp on the lemon juice and use fresh squeezed lemons, not the bottle stuff, yuk. You won't be disappointed.
I've also used pineapple juice in place of the lemon juice. It's delicious.

text:
WAY better than I expected.  A nice change from the typical ginger & soy varieties.   I agree with another reviewer - blending is a necessity rather than an option.  I didn't want globs of dried herbs coating the steaks only to be charred when on the grill.  Next time, however, I will probably cut the recipe in half as a lot of it was wasted - we had a little over 2lbs of ribeye steaks.  I also didn't use as much oil - it just wasn't necessary.  We will definitely make this one again.

Literally my favorite marinade to date, absolutely DELICIOUS. One side note: I would highly recommend following the instructions to the T and use a blender for at least 30 seconds. text:
One of the best marinades ever!!  I used 4 cloves of fresh chopped garlic instead of dried and skipped the parsley since I did not have it.  Mixed it together and used half of the marinade to marinate a flank steak and half  to marinate a bowl of sliced onions and bell peppers (2 onions sliced, 3 red bell peppers).  We ended up sautéing 1/2 of the onion mixture to serve with the steak that night.  A few days later, we cooked the rest of the onion mixture, mixed with leftover rice and steak for a stir-fry.  Such an amazing, versatile marinade!!   My family now requests I only use this marinade.

text:
I have been using this marinade for years, learned it from my mother... but I only put a couple quick squeezes of a fresh lemon in OR balsamic vinegar, small amount, never together. The meat doesn't get mushy and still browns beautifully on the grill. I don't feel you need to put in blender and I use fresh ground black pepper with fresh minced garlic. My BF doesn't like it because he likes to taste nothing by the steak but I think it enhances the taste of the meat. He is first person I have served it to in 40 years of cooking that doesn't care for it.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Another good one!  I tweaked it to what I had to use, combining with another recipe similar.  I used red wine vinegar, just a touch of Dijon, not so much dried herbs,  basil, some parsley, oregano, thyme and rosemary, extra garlic, as one can never have enough.  A couple drops of hot sauce, black pepper, no salt, used Aminos soy, (all natural, less sodium) avocado oil as I had NO virgin olive oil.   I whizzed it all in the blender and soaked for 2 days 5 sirloin steaks.  Very tasty despite being a very lean cut of meat.  We sadly overcooked them just a tad, but still enjoyed the great flavor.  A keeper!

text:
Inconsequential changes. Side note: 1/3 cup lemon is two very small lemons or (probably) one good sized one. I had a limited supply of basil so I supplemented with Italian Seasoning and didn't bother with the fresh garlic.

Look ... most marinades neither substantially change the flavor profile or do not  significantly make your meat more tender. This is a simple recipe that does both.

Used on Top Sirloin, made a significant impact. Beef approached filet mignon in tenderness and that was with only 2 hours. The other piece of meat will be cooked up with more time.

text:
Never...EVER...marinate beef with a high acid liquid like Lemon.  All you're doing is cooking it in acid.

I thought I'd try breaking this cardinal rule based on the number of positive reviews.  I now realize that there are just 2000 cooks out there who don't know anything about cooking steaks, and are basing their approval on some primordial flesh eating part of their brain and not because of a basic understanding about fine cuisine.

text:
I LOVE this steak marinade!!  I always have the ingredients on hand, as they're mostly pantry staples. This has quickly become my go to marinade.  I really love the flavor combination of garlic, soy sauce, Worcestershire and fresh lemon (to tenderize the meat).  I've used dried herbs per the recipe, which are good but expect it will be even better with fresh herbs from the garden. I cut the recipe in half, mix in a small bowl (no blender needed), pour into a ziplock bag to coat the steak, and toss it all in the fridge. I usually only marinate 1-2 hours- I'm not great at planning ahead- but with this recipe that's all that's needed for tons of flavor!!  Highly recommend this recipe. Thanks so much for sharing!!

Used this on venison backstrap. Cut it into 1.5" thick medallions and marinated overnight. Fried the steaks on med-high heat for 2 minutes each side, then finished in the oven at 400 degrees, about 7 minutes. Let them rest in foil about 10 minutes and they were DELICIOUS!!

text:
Absolutely flawless marinade. I stuck pretty much exactly to recipe and used it on sirloin.  Perfect cut for this marinade.  It was the best steak I've ever cooked.

I don't think blender is necessary.  I just put all ingredients in a gallon ziploc and shake it up then add steak.  For a single 1 lb. steak I cut the portions in half and it was still more than enough.  

Pan-seared the steak on medium high heat.  Came out medium/medium rare.  Perfection.  I was in awe with every bite.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time trying this recipe and boy IM GLAD I DID! I went to Costo with my wife and bought me some sirloin steaks to make the next the day. We went home and I started to do the marinade. I did the whole recipe but left out the hot pepper sauce and garlic salt because i replaced that with montreal steak seasoning(not on the actual recipe to blend) . Once I blended the recipe  I got 2 ziplog bags and before I put the steaks in there I sprinkled them with the montreal steak seasoning and it actually sticks to the steak right away. Put them on the bags carefully then i poured in the marinada and closed them up and put them on the fridge for about 17 hours give n take. Thats why put them the day before to marinate well. I put them on the grill once they were ready  we tried them and IT IS THE BEST STEAK I HAVE EVER TRIED!!!! I had bought A1 sauce as well cuz I always put them on my steaks and not this time! The flavor was so good I forgot about it! Definitely recomend this recipe! Will do it again soooooooon!

text:
This is the Best.The only difference in this recipe is that I left out the optional ingredients.   Got great reviews from wife and kids.   The second time I was asked to make this steak again and I had 3 1 1/4 inch thick sirloin steaks marinating.  
Life happened and I couldn't grill the steaks that night.  By the time I was able to grill the steaks it had marinated for 3 days in the fridge.  It still turned out perfectly.  Didn't look very good coming out of the Ziplock bag I had it in as the olive oil had clumped from the cold temps.  This time the family asked me to never try another recipe and always make steaks this way.  MAKE EXTRA STEAK so you have steak and eggs for breakfast the next day.

This marinade lives up to its name!  I have made a few times marinating an hour or two and it's good.   I marinated some steaks for a day and half and they tasted way better! BBQ is the best!

text:
My husband has always declared that he doesn't like marinated meat.  I do.  I decided to make two strip steaks and I marinated them in this recipe for 4 hours, then grilled them to medium.  I served the steaks and waited for a comment.  The comment was "what did you do to this steak?  It's fantastic!"  When I told hubs that I marinated the steaks, he said to keep doing it, as it was a "keeper".  The only changes I made to the recipe were- 1) I just mixed the marinade up in the zip lock bag and 2) I added 1 tablespoon of a smoky flavored barbeque sauce. (I halved the recipe)  So glad that I found this recipe!

Good marinade. I used all ingredients as suggested. Only had time to marinade for 5 hours so not sure how much difference it would have for a longer time marinating. I made kabobs with cut up rib eye pieces. Red onions, red and yellow peppers and mushrooms. The vegetables got marinated in the last 2 hours before being cooked while on kabobs and that was extra yummy. Will use again but try marinating longer to see if it makes a big difference because while it was good it wasn't amazing.

None
text:
The cut of meat you choose for this marinade is of high importance!  I had a variety of steaks: Porterhouse, Ribeye, and Filet.  I marinaded them all about 2 hours.  The Filet and Porterhouse were PERFECT.   This is a marinade I will go to regularly for those cuts in the future.  The Ribeye, however, were EXTREMELY salty!!  Clearly, the higher fat content/marbling allowed more salt to be absorbed.  These were almost inedible.   I will either use this marinade for a much shorter length of time, or change recipes altogether.

city:

region:

country:

text:
I had a ton of fresh garlic and basil to use up, but otherwise followed the recipe as is.  This marinade was delicious on the top sirloin steaks we grilled for dinner tonight.  We marinated them for about 3 hours, turning once.  It has so much delicious flavor, but doesn't overpower the natural flavor of the meat the way vinegar-based marinades usually do.  This marinade would be even better on chicken, pork, or seafood, in my opinion.  I made a double batch, and poured it into a quart size Mason jar to keep in the fridge.  I plan to try it on some zucchini I want to grill, too.  Thank you for sharing!

OMG - Amazing.  I was a little dubious about this recipe - I mean, herbs in a marinade for beef?  But of all the recipes I looked at this one was the only one that I had all the ingredients on hand for.  And frankly, it looks like sludge when it comes out of the blender.  But I used it on a thick piece of  supermarket-grade sirloin for about an hour and a half at room temp., then put it on the grill, first for about 15 minutes to sear, and then on indirect medium, and it came out juicy and extremely delicious.  This recipe is a keeper.

text:
Wow, boys and girls this is terrific!!  Have you ever mixed something and taken a long look only to say to yourself: "am I going to put $25.00 worth of steaks into something that looks like the cat had been eating grass!"  You taste the marinade and almost pitch it but then you throw caution to the wind and decide to try it.  Even when cooking I thought I would get surprise...then I couldn't wait any longer and cut a small piece while still on the grill.  My goodness!!  My tonsils started to slap my taste buds silly!!!!

I didn't change a thing other than I didn't ad the hot sauce (I have surgery in the morning and am supposed to be NPO after midnight.  

Steak lovers, you have to try this marinade, it is to die for!!  Thanks for sharing this with us common folk...we are not worthy??!!

text:
Made this for Father's Day with bone-in ribeyes.  Was told by all it was the best steak they have every had.  I made a couple of changes...but only because I'm an idiot.  I put ingredients in the blender and after pouring the marinade on the steaks, looked over and saw the lemon juice still sitting there...so that didn't go in.  I also wanted to add a little molasses because a friend of ours makes awesome steaks and uses it in his marinade.  I didn't realize I had run out, so I used honey instead.  All of my scatterbrainedness turned out well enough that I will replicate this mess in the future.  :)

Can out really well, marinating a steak for about an hour before hitting the charcoal. So well, in fact, that I refrig'd the leftover marinade, and marinated some chicken thighs a day later, which came out really nicely as well. Had plenty of flavor, and nice complexity with basil, parsley, Worcestershire, etc.

Excellent on top sirloin I used for Shish Kebobs. I cut the basil back to 2 tablespoons, omitted the hot sauce and used minced jar garlic instead of the dried, probably 2 tsps of that. text:
Made this marinade as written in the recipe, minus the optional ingredients. It was delicious!! I left out the hot sauce since my wife doesn't like spicy food. Next time I will add the optional minced garlic since we love garlic and it could have had a bit more punch to the marinade.
One word of caution, the lemon juice might be a little intense for those that don't like that acidic punch, so you may want to reduce the amount by a little bit.
Otherwise, I'd easily call this 5 stars as written.

text:
Good marinade recipe, especially with the addition of soy sauce.  Only changes made were to use light soy sauce and fresh herbs, garlic & pureed onion vs. the dried that this recipe calls for.   Always looking for a marinade recipe that tops our family favorite and while this came close, we still prefer the Best Steak Marinade recipe found in the International Bellhop Magazine published on June 19, 2013.  This recipe calls for lighter herbs and the addition of V-8 juice, which we have fallen in love with.  However, I'd make this marinade again just for change in taste over the grilling season.

text:
GREAT marinade.  This marinade gives the steak amazing flavor and they come out juicy every time.

The only issue I have is the call for it to be marinated for up to 8 hours in the fridge.  Because of the olive oil, if you refrigerate this marinade, it eventually congeals and the steak can't absorb it.  Better would have been to offer some instruction on how long to marinate it at room temperature before /after refrigeraing or before cooking.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This really is a great marinade. I let 1" and 2" ribeyes marinate for almost 24 hrs flipping them twice (once before bed and again in morning). They did NOT over marinate. Everyone loved it. It will be hard to deviate doing something different when this is so good.

 I used fresh basil instead. I added fresh minced garlic, and some hot sauce. I doubled the recipe and it was enough for 6 lbs of ribeyes. I would guess marinating for 8 hours or less will produce a very delicate flavor enhancing the steak. Next time if the timing works out, I'll try for 8 hours and see how it's different. 
I also wonder if I substituted balsamic vinegar instead of lemon juice? Maybe then 24hrs may be too much.

Updated 5/1/2016
I followed recipe and ended up marinating the ribeyes marinate for 28 hours because of having a late dinner.. Definitely too long.

Display Name:
Kawlijah

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So I made this recipe as is the very first time and it had WAY to many dried herbs. It gave the steak this awful texture and you just got a mouthful of dried up herbs... 

I made it a second time and edited what I did. First I cut everything in half. I used 1/4 cup olive oil, 1/4 cup soy sauce (full sodium), and 1/6 cup worsteshire. Added 2 tsp minced garlic, 1 tsp garlic powder, 1 tbs basil, 1 tbs parsley, 1 tbs lemon juice, 1/4 tsp hot sauce and let it marinade for an hour at room temperature (my steaks were cold when I stuck them in the marinade- I just left it out long enough for my steaks to hit room temperature). 

Seared the steaks in a hot pan to get some nice color on both sides. Cooked mine to rare and the husbands to medium. It was awesome with those adjustments.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fantastic flavor.  I have made this for over a year now and it works great on beef steak and cubed pork loin. I have even used it on roasts. I like to marinade the meat for a day in the refrigerator,  and I try to avoid freezing my meat now.  Not sure why but two identical packages of rib-eye steak bought at the same time. I froze one, the other marinated with this recipe over night and bar-b-qued was fantastic. The frozen steak was frozen for 2 weeks, thawed and marinated over night and bar-b-qued was great but not fantastic.  

With the high cost of meat I have tried this on lower quality cuts and it is always with  fantastic results!  The pork loin bar-b-ques nicely cut in 1 inch cubes in this marinade and a chopped purple onion, in a wire cooking basket.

text:
I added all the ingredients besides lemon juice because I forgot and I also mixed an egg, and cayenne in with the rest of the ingredients. I let it sit for 6 hours with my meat and then heated butter up in a pan and poured it all and cooked on medium-low til tender and cooked. I almost made rice and cut the meat up into small pieces. I turned the rest of the juices into a gravy with half-half milk and flour with a little bit of water.  I mixed it all in the rice and served it.  Was awesome! I will make again and I will try it with lemon juice to see if I can tell the difference or which one I prefer to make.

userID:
16949813
Display Name:
ktndiver51
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3

8

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made it per directions the first time. It was good. No doubt about it. I then made it again leaving out the optional items and replacing the white pepper with black pepper (I forgot to get white pepper at the store). I then got into some weird experimental mindset. I went a little strong in every ingredient,but I also went closer to 2-2.5 TBS of Worcestershire sauce (I love that stuff, anyway) and did not use a blender to mix, just a fork. I let the steaks (rib eye, both times) sit for 4 hours. Took them out of the marinate and covered one side with the drippings. While it was on the grill I put the marinate on the up side and then flipped. Again, I put marinate on the up side, flipped one more time, repeat. I cooked the steaks to medium. A true medium not the  you get at restaurants. I liked it the first time but, . The variation I made, made my wife say, "this is the best steak I ever ate." Which obviously boosted my ego but, I had to agree. Great recipe.....Thanks for sharing!
P.S. I used this recipe for 2 16 oz steaks.....I did 4 with the first attempt. I also only put the steaks in the fridge for  the first 2 hours and, they were killed the same day (both times, I always go to a local butcher).

5

region:

country:
None
text:
I have used this marinade few times already and it had given me pretty good results. And keep in mind how your steak will come out depends on many other factors, such us the cut o meat, the grill temperature and grilling time,..
Back to the marinade, I just whisk the ingredients in a bowl and then pour over the steaks in a Ziploc bag. I had use vinegar for lemon juice couple of times and that didn't affect the recipe, cause both lemon juice and vinegar are acids that tenderize and break down the meat fibers, allowing the spices and herbs to infuse the steak with flavor.

text:
My son made this while I watched, he said the steaks were cheap ones I don't know but this was the best steak we have ever had.  He did as directed with one change he used 1/2 Asian soy soy sauce which is lower in salt and 1/2 regular soy sauce.  With that said we thought the only change would be to use all asian or reduced salt soy sauce.  We thought it was just a bit salty but man that stopped no one. 
He did blend it in blender and I do think that helped make this marinatde in that it kind of imalsified the dry herbs n spices.
It did not look very nice.
Marinated overnight grilled over charcoal the next day.

I didn't have half of the ingredients on this list, but decided to give it a try anyways with just mushroom soy sauce, olive oil, lemon juice, and fresh garlic. I added a little bit of chili oil and black pepper and marinated overnight. I can't afford to buy the best quality and cuts of meat, so I don't buy it very often, but on the rare occasion I do buy steak as a treat, this marinade is just what I need to make those inferior cuts tender, flavorful, and satisfying.

userID:
16340793
Display Name:
Victus
isPro:

1
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very Good and flexible marinade recipe. By that I mean you can "Asian"  it up a bit by adding 1/4 c. of fresh or pickled ginger and 2-3 tbps. of sesame oil and cutting back olive oil to 1/4 c.   Use the minced garlic in this marinade.
I use some of the marinade (2/3 c.) for an Au Jus by adding 1/4 c. red wine or cooking sherry, 1 tbsp.  molasses or maple syrup.  Since you have meat juices in the used marinade - heat the mixture up to a light boil in a small sauce pan.  Skim off the foam caused by the cooking beef juices if some appears on top.     For lamb chops add to the base recipe 1-tbsp. dried mint or more to taste and 1- tsp. coriander,  then add the wine and molasses/maple syrup for the Au Jus.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

I made this recipe on the fly and loved it.  Best steak recipe I've found to date!  Made steaks very flavorful and tasty! I didn't have white ground pepper so I used black ground pepper instead. Also used fresh basil leaves instead of dried, just doubled what the recipe called for.  Looking forward to many more barbecues!

text:
What is great about this recipe besides the fact that it kicks a ___ is it is simple.  I didn't have to work at it and had all the ingredients already.  I was glad I had picked up a real lemon because its important to use fresh in this (super lively).  I did not use the blender either and halved the recipe for two good sized New York steaks and it covered them well.  Used a few drops of Tapatio for kick. Only marinaded for 3 hours which I found to be perfectly fine.  Thanks for sharing your family's recipe!

text:
Green, but GOOD! Very, very good!!  Of course I changed it up and would like to share my version, as it turned out so wonderful. This will be my new and exclusive marinade, and the one I will be sharing with friends. I used Teaspoons instead of Tablespoons of the garlic, basil and parsley, and a half Teaspoon of black pepper, and added a chopped onion which I grilled on a mat alongside the steak. YUM!  I felt the larger quantities would be too overbearing. So for those of you who didn't like the original, try tweaking it like I did. You're going to love it now!!

I used this recipe for a steak marinade for the second time yesterday and just love the taste. I really like the basil taste even though the second time I cut down the basil to about 2 tablespoons. text:
DELICIOUS!!!!! Didn't blend the recipe but did put it in a ziplock bag and shook it like a Polaroid picture. Insert two New York strips. I froze this for two days then took it out and laid it on the counter for ten (10) hours for de thawing and coming to room temp which is apparently the secret to a tender steak. Cooked them in a cast iron skillet on medium hi for four (4) minutes on each side and let sit for 4 minutes prior to serving. They were delicious. One of the best marinades I've ever had re pleasure of cooking  with. Thanks for the recipe. Saving and can't wait to find two good filets to use it on.

I Marinated some chuck eye steaks in it for about 3 or 4 hours and then cooked them on the grill for 5 min on each side they were so tender & juicy I could cut them with a fork and these were cheep steaks they were so delicious they tasted like an expensive ribeye.So I say again OH MY GOD!!! Everyone you've got to try this marinade it's delicious.Thanks. Will

text:
Delicious, we used it on rump steaks on the BBQ. I didn't whizz this up either. Just popped in a sarnie bag and marinated for 4/5 hours. We also went without the hot sauce and used rapeseed instead of olive oil as I prefer the flavour and its cooking tolerance. I find olive oil better at lower temps (we seared the beef high and cooked low).
Highly recommend, will certainly be using this recipe from now on and can't want to try it on other meats! Best marinade yet :)

text:
I put this marinade together for a top round from our butcher not store bought beef. I don't normally use Asian flavors for western raised beef. I like to stay close to tradition. That said I took some liberties with this recipes. I have many years experience with marinades, rubs and tenderizers. I added onion powder, salt and fresh ground black pepper and to tenderize in a shorter time frame I added some cider vinegar. I must say I will use the soy more often. It really surprised me on the flavor. And the vinegar added a nice tang. Thanks for the tip.

text:
Love, love, love this marinade!  I followed the recipe exactly except cut ingredients in half since I was cooking a 1 3/4" lb. sirloin.  Only marinated for a couple of hours; cooked the steak in a hot cast iron skillet for about 3 min. on each side; finished it off in a 375 degree oven for 6-7 min.; then covered with foil to rest for 5 min.  Perfect tasty medium rare steak!  Will definitely allow enough time to marinate longer the next time.

This marinade is simple and quick. I had 7 lbs. of USDA Top Sirloin. The steak chilled in the fridge for about 3 hours. Fired up the grill. Seared the meat, grilled the steak until the center was a nice pink color - medium rare. I let it sit for about 10 minutes. Took the first bite. Absolutely loved it. Even sopped up a little of the juice from my plate onto the steak. My taste buds were in heaven.

userID:
11805824
Display Name:
kdgreer777
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
13
favoritesCount:
40
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great marinade. I made it exactly to specs adding the optional hot pepper sauce and (fresh) minced garlic. I put 2 huge T-bones in a ziploc bag with the marinade and flipped them over every 30 min to an hour for 6 hours. Set left 2 burners on grill to full blast and left the right 2 off. After grill reached about 600 degrees, I seared both sides for 3 minutes on direct heat side then put the steaks on the indirect heat side. Using a electronic thermometer, I closed the lid and let the internal temperature slowly creep up to 140°F. Steaks came out perfect. The only concern is that some of my guests may want more "steak" flavor than I got from the marinade at 6 hours. Next time, will marinate for 4 - 4 1/2 hours and see if it doesn't come out with a little more beef flavor. All in all, my daughter excitedly ate 2 helpings (1 before even touching her favorite food, mashed potatos and gravy)and my wife said it was one of the best steaks she had ever had, period. Many thanks for the recipe. It will be put in my "bag of tricks" and I will definitely be seeing it again.

Rating:
2
dateLastModified:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sorry...but it is NOT the best steak marinade in existence.  I'm always open to trying new recipes while keeping an open mind about the outcome.  We grow our own beef, mostly use very simple but effective marinades and seasonings without fail.  Because of all the rave reviews, gave this one a try. Its got to be the lemon juice, it just doesn't belong in a meat marinade in my opinion. I will give it 2 stars for the fact that it did make our flank steak very tender (I marinated overnight) and used the remaining sauce to marinate chicken for the following night.  Will stick to my never-fail marinade sauce from here on!

country:
None
text:
Excellent marinade, have used it many times.  Only change I made was to use fresh garlic (about 6 cloves, chopped) instead of minced, and a tablespoon of hot sauce.  Marinated 2 large flank steaks overnight, then instead of throwing marinade out, put 2 frozen boneless chicken breasts in bag and had those the next night.  I did not use the blender, just a bowl & whisk , then poured in the ziplock with meat....easy...

text:
We found this to be just OK. I made it and marinated the steak as directed, but there was just such a mish-mash of flavors that it ended up tasting strongly of nothing in particular, if that makes sense to anyone but me. Usually a marinade tastes strongly of one of its ingredients and the others are just there to play supporting roles, but in this marinade, there didn't seem to be a "star" ingredient.

text:
Loved it! My husband has never been a huge fan of marinades, but upon tasting his steak exclaimed, "I WANT THIS MARINADE ON MY SOUL!". Haha, we both enjoyed it very much and have used it several times. I didn't put it in the blender, just mixed it up in a gallon sized ziploc and threw the meat in. I hated to pour such goodness down the drain when we were done, so I threw a few frozen chicken breasts in the bag and let it refrigerate for about two days (we couldn't get to it any faster). It was SO GOOD!

text:
This was good.  As per other reviews I will drop the Olive Oil as I made the mistake of making this the night before and the Oil went solid as Olive Oil does if you put it into a fridge.  All was not lost and I marinaded the steak with the remaining liquid, then fried two minutes on each side, then put the cast iron pan in a pre-heated oven for 5 minutes.  The steak tasted reaaly really good.  It could be a bit strong for some people, but I really liked it and would make again.  It makes enough for several steaks.

This was so good. We ended up leaving it on our steaks for about three days and the flavor was incredible. I was a little worried about the lemon flavor because I don't really like lemon on my food. I just dropped them into a ziploc bag, mixed them and added the steaks. They lay flat in fridge until it was time to broil them. Thanks for a good recipe.

text:
I have mixed feelings about this.  My steaks were incredibly tender after marinating for 24 hours, so it has that going for it.  But, the marinade itself has a weird, earthy flavor to it (because of all those spices).  I was not a huge fan.  It didn't have an overpowering taste on the steak, but I did was one reviewer suggested - I coated the mushrooms with the marinade and cooked them.  You could really tell the marinade's taste with the mushrooms, and it was not pleasant.  It was a little dirty tasting.

I came across this recipe wanting to try a new marinade. I have to say that I was surprised!
Everyone loved it! Even my mom who is not a steak person said it herself.

Will defiantly be making this again. :)

text:
This is THE marinade! I've made it several times and I always get rave reviews from my family and guests. It's as good on chicken thighs as it is on steaks. 
Here are my few adjustments: I use vegetable oil, instead of olive oil. I use 1-2 fresh, minced garlic cloves, instead of dried. And, I never keep dried parsley, so I skip that altogether. 
This recipe is a real winner.

text:
How could I not try it with this title?!  It is awfully good - didn't overpower the meat, but tenderized a cheap cut nicely.  The changes I will make next time are to use just real minced garlic instead of powder, and to cut back on the "green stuff" - too much basil and parsley in my opinion.  A tablespoon of each would be more than enough to get the flavor in there, without coating everything in moss-like crud (ending in a nicer presentation).

text:
This is such a great flavorful marinade.  I left out the hot sauce and minced garlic.  I used almost a 3lb london broil.  First, I rubbed it with garlic and onion powder and season salt.  Let that sit for 1-2 hours.  Then wisked all the marinade ingredients together and poured it over top.  Soaked that for another 1-2 hours.  Then broiled it for 10ish min or so on each side. Perfect!  Will definitely use this recipe all the time.

Display Name:
Amaris1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/313842.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this the first time for Mother's Day and my family really liked it.  I had only been able to let it marinade for that day and I used whole beef tenderloin.  At first I thought it was ok but found myself wanting more later in the evening and had to make it again.  This time I used whole beef tenderloin again and I was able to let it marinade for 2 days.  I also used about 1/2 of the lemon juice and I used about 1/4 cup of balsamic vinegar.  It is more of an acidic flavor and if you crust the meat up a little by having a nice hot grill, the crusty meat and marinade flavor dances on your tongue a lot longer.  I also didn't find the need to blend the mixture.  I haven't tried using fresh herbs yet especially because there' s so much flavor with the dried, plus I also used a tablespoon of dried oregano too.  I enjoyed this and will again and again.

5

country:
None
text:
This recipe is everything it claims to be and more! I marinated some steaks and veggies for kabobs using this marinade and it was delicious. They all marinated for about 8 hours before grilling and I served over couscous and my guests loved it. Threre wasn't a single kabob left. Very flavorful, but not too overwhelming. The only thing I would change is using a reduced-sodium soy sauce since I have hyptertension and try to follow a low-sodium diet. It was a bit salty for me, but none of the other more healthier guests had the same issue. Also, I didn't have white pepper so your garden-variety black pepper worked just as well.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
this is an excellent marinade.  Fairly salty but great flavor.  I buy sirloin filets, cut into 1 inch pieces.  marinate overnight. I don't use the hot pepper sauce and instead of dried minced garlic use 2 minced garlic cloves.  Skewer then grill for 8 minutes.  I've made this for company 2x and it's been a huge crowd pleaser.  Be sure to serve with something like  feta couscous or rice-you dont want to overpower the flavor.  I highly recommned this marinade.

None
text:
About 3 average lemons to equal 1/3 cup. Roll them on the counter before you cut them and the juice will release and be easier to squeeze. I don't think you would need to blend the ingredients. Just add them all to a bag. The oil will make everything stick to the sides of whatever you are mixing in. Mix yourself and then add the meat. You can add or take out anything but I think this is a great marinade!!

text:
Literally the BEST homemade marinade ever! I used all ingredients as listed (even the optionals), but didn't see a need to blend it. Since you're marinating in plastic ziploc baggies anyway, I saved the dirty dishes and just mixed it up in the bag before adding the steaks. This recipe was the perfect amount for 2 HUGE steaks with enough leftover to brush on while grilling. We also brushed veggie skewers (zucchini, summer squash, mushrooms, red pepper) with the marinade and they were fantastic! Thanks :)

userID:
4364287
Display Name:
MissVee
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
560
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/697606.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I needed to find a marinade for the lamb chops I made today for Easter dinner.  I used this recipe because it was very easy to make and had such great reviews.  Since I was making lamb, I decide to replace the basil with rosemary.  I didn't have enough rosemary, so I wound up using 2 Tbsp parsley, 1 Tbsp rosemary and 1/2 Tbsp thyme.  I also added 1/2 tsp of a mixed black/red pepper spice and 1 tsp of brown mustard (I didn't have Dijon).  I blended the mixture, poured it over the lamb and let it marinate in the refrigerator for 5 hours.  When it was time to cook the lamb, I poured off the excess marinade and grilled the chops on high heat.  The lamb cooked beautifully on the grill.  The meat was very tender and flavorful.  No need for steak sauce or gravy.  The marinade added flavor, but did not overpower the meat.  I caught my son sucking the small bits of meat off of the lamb bones.  He really loved this recipe and so did my husband and I!  Thank you for sharing this recipe.

region:

country:
None
text:
Best marinade in existence seemed rather optimistic, but I figured I would try it out.  I get pretty tired of soy sauce based marinades, it seems as though 99% of marinades have soy in there.  I was a little skeptical because of the soy, but it is quite subtle.  Overall, I thought this was excellent.  I did blend it but I don't really see the need for it.  Nice thing about the blending is the herbs get ground up and all over the steak.  I also used the extra marinade to cook mushrooms in, that was a great idea.  They were terrific.  We will definitely use this several times.  I can say it is the best steak marinade I have made.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Really liked this recipe! After reading a lot of reviews, my changes were....used low sodium soy sauce, only 1 tablespoon garlic powder, 1 teaspoon dried basil, lowered pepper amount to 1/2 teaspoon (not a pepper lover). Added 1 tablespoon brown sugar, 1 teaspoon minced garlic from a jar, and 1 teaspoon onion powder. I will use this marinade again, but might only use 1/3 cup olive oil. It makes a large amount. I only had about 2 hours to let the meat soak. I used it on a top round and then cooked it on the George Forman grill. Husband came back for thirds! He left just enough for one meal today, lol. Guess I'll be nice and let him enjoy it one more time. I would agree, it's the best!

My husband and some friends went crazy for this recipe!  (i'm a vegetarian, so i didn't eat any steak but i can tell you that marinade smelled amazing)  I did cut half the basil because i thought that 4 1/2 tbsp dried herbs was a little heavy and dried basil gets overpowering, in my opinion.  Also, i was in a hurry, so i didn't blend it, i just whipped it in a bowl and then put it in a ziploc with the steak.  I massaged the steak and flipped the bag over every 20-30 minutes and everyone said it turned out great.  I'll definitely make this again!

text:
Wow, this marinade was really good!  Like another reviewer suggested, I poured the leftover marinade in a pan, added mushrooms, cooked until most of the liquid was gone (making sure to cook at a higher temp to get rid of bacteria!!), and served the mushrooms atop the steak.  The mushrooms were to die for!  I might keep a batch of marinade on hand just as a sauce for sautéing the mushrooms in!  The steak was good too, of course. :)  I broiled the steaks and accidentally cooked them a bit too long, but the marinade was tasty!  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
This recipe actually caused me to start eating red meat again; I didn't know it could taste this good! I love, love, LOVE this marinade. I mainly follow the recipe, though I use fresh garlic (to taste) and fresh basil, and I leave out the hot sauce. I let the meat marinate for at least a day; three days if I have the time. I find this is great to prepare on the weekend and let marinate, and then cook up during the week when I want an quick but tasty dinner.  Thanks so much for sharing!!!

text:
I cut the recipe back a bit, since i was only marinating one rather large chunk of steak. I used real minced garlic instead of dried, and added a 1/2 cup of Merlot. Whisked it all together in a bowl and poured over steak in gallon-freezer bag, marinated 1 1/2 days. Cooked in the oven. I never got to taste it, but my son ate the entire piece of meat (enough for 3 people). He literally couldn't stop going back for more!  Next time I will get to try it too. No need to look any further for a marinade recipe this is it!!   Thanks SO much for this great recipe.

text:
This recipe was great. I did blend it, but I don't really see why you have to. I was a little hesitant about adding the hot sauce because I don't like my food to be even a little spicy, but I added it because my husband likes hot sauce. You couldn't really taste it, so I'm not sure whether it would be any different without it. I let the steaks marinade for about 24 hours and they were excellent. I'll definitely use this again. *Update* This is now the only marinade I will use for steak. Even my husband, who isn't big on using recipes, asks that I use this one specifically. :)
